name: vladimiralexiev.github.io
tagline: Stuff that varies from eclectic to non-existent
body:
# Presentations
* SmartCulture Conference, 2014-06-11, Brussels, Belgium: **Semtech for CH**: [2D interactive HTML](pres/20140611-SmartCulture-sem-tech-CH/index.html), [printable PDF](pres/20140611-SmartCulture-sem-tech-CH/Semantic Technologies for Cultural Heritage.pdf), [slideshare](http://www.slideshare.net/valexiev1/semantic-technologies-for-cultural-heritage-35749530)
* Malmo Linked Data [Meetup](http://www.meetup.com/Linked-Data-in-Business/events/198356552/), 2014-08-21, Malmo, Sweden: **Semtech for CH**: [2D interactive HTML](pres/20140821-Malmo/index.html), [pribtable PDF](pres/20140821-Malmo/SemTechCH-Malmo.pdf), [Youtube video](http://youtu.be/n8oGmOu9JEw)
* CIDOC Congress, Dresden, Germany. **Getty Vocabulary Program LOD: Ontologies and Semantic Representation**: 2014-09-05: International Terminology Working Group: [2D interactive full version (HTML)](pres/20140905-CIDOC-GVP/index.html), 2014-09-09: Getty special session: [short printable version (PDF)](pres/20140905-CIDOC-GVP/GVP-LOD-CIDOC-short.pdf)
* [NKOS 2014 Workshop](https://at-web1.comp.glam.ac.uk/pages/research/hypermedia/nkos/nkos2014/programme.html), London, UK, 12 Sep 2014: **On Compositionality of ISO 25964 Hierarchical Relations (BTG, BTP, BTI)**: [2D interactive HTML](pres/20140912-NKOS-compositionality/index.html)

# Multisensor
* [Multisensor Linked Data](Multisensor/Multisensor-LD.html): web presentation 2014-05-19, Barcelona

## Linguistic Linked Data

There's been a huge drive in recent years to represent NLP data as RDF. NLP data is usually large, so does it make sense to represent it as RDF? What's the benefit?

Ontologies, schemas and groups include: GRaF ITS2 FISE LAF LD4LT LEMON LIME LMF MARL NERD NIF NLP2RDF OLIA OntoLex OntoLing OntoTag Penn Stanford... my oh my!

There are a lot of linguistic resources available that can be used profitably: BabelNet FrameNet GOLD ISOcat LemonUBY Multitext OmegaNet UBY VerbNet Wiktionary WordNet.

* Zotero Linguistic LD bibliography: https://www.zotero.org/groups/linguistic_ld/items
* [NIF-example.ttl](Multisensor/NIF-example.ttl): example of NLP data in RDF (Turtle). Covers NIF (text binding), OLIA (linguistic properties), Penn (POS tagging), Stanford (dependency parsing), ITS20 (semantic annotation), NERD (entity extraction classes), Stanbol/FISE (multiple NLP tools/annotations per word/phrase), MARL (opinion/sentiment); and use of entities from DBpedia, WordNet, YAGO.
  * [NIF-example.ttl.html](Multisensor/NIF-example.ttl.html): syntax-highlighted with Emacs htmlize
  * [NIF-example.json](Multisensor/NIF-example.json): same in JSON-LD, shows that Turtle should be used for examples/discussion/QA and JSON-LD for machine communication only
* Issues I've found in NIF: 
  * [Issue 1](https://github.com/NLP2RDF/specification/issues/1): nif:opinion vs marl:extractedFrom. Example: [NIF-issue-1.ttl](Multisensor/NIF-issue-1.ttl)
  * [Issue 2](https://github.com/NLP2RDF/specification/issues/2): itsrdf vs fise properties. Example: [NIF-issue-2.ttl](Multisensor/NIF-issue-2.ttl)
* [Linguistic Linked Data](Multisensor/Linguistic-LD.html): presentation, TODO

# Getty Vocabulary Program LOD
[GVP Semantic Representation](aat/index.htm): draft.

Official versions:
* http://vocab.getty.edu/doc/: HTML for linking 
* http://vocab.getty.edu/doc/gvp-lod.pdf: PDF for printing

# Ontotext Research Projects
[Frame that displays the project timeline](Ontotext-FP-projects-timeline.html) at http://www.ontotext.com/EC_ResearchProjects. 
It uses a Google Sheet and Google Charts

# SPARQL Syntax Diagrams
Syntax (rail-road) diagrams of SPARQL 1.1 Query Language. I use this quite often while writing SPARQL

* [sparql11-grammar.xhtml](SPARQL/sparql11-grammar.xhtml): Cross-linked diagrams, one per production (173 total). 
A bit hard to understand: use this for reference, but not for learning SPARQL.
Here's a [chunked diagram](http://ontologicalengineering.blogspot.com/2008/12/sparql-railroad-diagram-from-hell.html), which however is partial: [Discussion](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15758282/bigger-granularity-railroad-diagram-generator) whether there's a chunked generator
* [sparql11-grammar.ebnf](SPARQL/sparql11-grammar.ebnf): EBNF rules extracted from the spec
* [sparql11-grammar.txt](SPARQL/sparql11-grammar.txt): same thing but with production numbers

Notes:
* extracted from: http://www.w3.org/TR/sparql11-query/
* version: http://www.w3.org/TR/2013/REC-sparql11-query-20130321/
* created on: Tue Apr 2, 2013, 08:59 (UTC+03)
* created by: vladimir.alexiev at ontotext dot com
* created with: http://bottlecaps.de/rr/ui 

This tool is quite good: it can scrape EBNF grammars from W3C specs, generates either a single XHTML with embedded SVG, or a zip with many PNGs, cross-links the definitions and usages.
note: Don't delete this file! It's used internally to help with page regeneration.
